posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked:
FRC Team 6995 is proud to present the CAD for our 2025 Robot: Mariana!

Onshape

Behind the Bumpers

We want to highlight a few changes our team has made in preparation of champs:

Even though we had tons of success intaking at the station at Orange County, as the defensive meta evolved, we began to struggle under heavy defense. In order to be competitive at worlds, we decided to make the switch to a ground hand. After 30 iterations of trying different wheels and minor customizations, we landed on our final hand. Hand v5 AS - NOMAD 2025 3296×2547 1.7 MB

Hand v5 AS - NOMAD 2025 3296×2547 1.7 MB

Hand v5 AS - NOMAD 2025 3296×2547 1.7 MB

Our new hand additionally allows us to score coral on both sides of our robot for levels 3 and 4, as well as take algae off the reef on both sides. We are hoping to get 4-5 more cycles per match with this improvement. Huge thanks to 9442 and 8033 for helping us get this working!

During the season, our hook climber struggled to hold itself up for more than 3 seconds, and towards the end of the season, started to dip in reliability. Earlier in the season we prototyped a wheeled climber, but for the sake of simplicity we went with our hooked version. After seeing many top teams have success with the wheeled style climb, we revived our old prototype and switched back to the wheel-based latch climber. Climb 2.0 AM - NOMAD 2025 3296×2547 1.43 MB

Climb 2.0 AM - NOMAD 2025 3296×2547 1.43 MB

Climb 2.0 AM - NOMAD 2025 3296×2547 1.43 MB

This new version should reduce our climb time from 15 seconds to 5-7 seconds.

Feel free to leave any questions or inquiries on this thread and we would be happy to answer!

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked: This robot is one of the cleanest ones that I have seen this year. Congrats on an amazing season and hoping to see y’all make Einsteins!

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked:
this is such a cool robot

nocad?

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked: The iteration throughout the season looks great! Good luck in your division, twin.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: I see you’re going for the motorized wheel cage grabber. But, going for one pole instead of both. How’s that working out? Any reason for the single vs double?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: The single pole grabber was something we built for our Week 3 event but didn’t end up using. At the time it stuck out perpendicular to the elevator and we found that it had trouble pulling in the pipe and did not pull the eye bolt down enough to get us off the ground. Instead of building a 2-pipe climber, we angled our existing one up 12 degrees, which let it be outside the bumpers for grabbing and pull the eye bolt an extra inch+ lower. It works well now.

posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked: We went with the single pole design over the dual pole because from our testing we found that you could slam into the cage at any angle and it would almost always grab a corner. This means less time to line up for the driver.

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked: We have something similar and I can tell you a motorized set of wheels looking for a single pole works a lot easier and  faster to lock in the cage. With the cage swinging, it’s still just as quick.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: This concept may end up on our off season bot! Thanks for the insight.

posts.name: Gabriel McMahon
posts.cooked: Love the design! Your brainpan design is pretty different from others I’ve seen, how easy is it to access when in a rush? Also, see a lot of 3d prints around your pivot, what filament are you using, and have you had any trouble with pieces breaking?

posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked:
To access the electronics underneath, we flip the robot on the side and take off the polycarb cover on the bottom, just a few bolts into rivnuts. Only takes about 30 seconds and we are ready to work on whatever we need.

The 3D prints on the pivot are made out of PLA pro (iirc), and nothing has broken. This is because they aren’t actually taking any load, all of them are there to be a spacer, or constrain something axially.

posts.name: Bpk9p4
posts.cooked: hat’s a very cool robot! I was looking at your CAD and didn’t quite understand how your friction brake worked. Could you explain that a little
It was awesome watching this bot cook on einstein. How do you deal with backlash when a lot of the gear reductions on the pivot come from gear to gear interaction?

All the gears on the pivot mech are from REV, we have found that they have a tighter hex bore than other hex gears. When we were assembling the pivot, we made sure to shim tape all the gears too, so each one was a tight press fit on hex shaft. In addition, each kraken pinion was green loctited to their spline xs shafts. In our competitions, routine checking and tightening of the #35 chain when required helped us to have very minimal backlash on our arm.

posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked:
Sure! Below is a section view with all of the labeled components. Screenshot 2025-04-21 at 6.21.29 PM 1015×575 217 KB The vortex is driving a WCP rubber friction brake on an 8mm lead screw. This gets pushed into a lathed down aluminum hex hub, which is on the same shaft as one of our gears for the pivot (early in the reduction so minimal force is needed). In the gif below you can see the very small range of motion, and where the rubber pad and hex hub interfere (the red).

Screenshot 2025-04-21 at 6.21.29 PM 1015×575 217 KB

Screenshot 2025-04-21 at 6.21.29 PM 1015×575 217 KB

Additionally, the free spinning motor is very helpful for field setup and manual positioning. Please let me know if you would like more information, happy to share.
